pageContext.title: Redesigning Buffer‚Ää: A UX case study
pageContext.content:
The following case study is part of my submission for Buffer‚Äôs design challenge.

Buffer is a content scheduling platform. Its iOS and Android apps help agencies, brands, and publishers schedule, manage, and track the performance of all their social profiles in one place.

The problem

Here are some specific pain points users have shared:

  • It‚Äôs challenging to get an overview of scheduled content at a glance.
  • It can be difficult to identify gaps in the upcoming content schedule.
  • It‚Äôs not easy to quickly move or reschedule content.

The ask: Make a solution to give users an overview of their scheduled content, while making it simple to spot and fill gaps in their schedule, all within a mobile app.

Deliverables

  • Process‚Ää: How did you arrive at your final solution? What constraints did you consider? How did you keep the user top of mind? Show us the ‚Äúwhy‚Äù behind your work.
  • Solution‚Ää: Show us what your final solution looks like and how it works.
  • Breakdown‚Ää: ‚ÄäInclude any interaction notes, context, or other helpful details your future team will need to make your solution a reality.

My approach

I approached the exercise in five parts:

  1. Understanding the task:¬†Contextual analysis, constraints, and assumptions
  2. Defining audience: When/where, user context, and needs
  3. Exploring ideas: Sketches, lightning demos, user interactions
  4. Visual design: Reiterating sketches and ideas
  5. Conclusions: Measure success and future explorations

Understanding the¬†task

I immediately started taking notes after I got the exercise. It allowed me to immerse into the problem and understand the task at hand. Once I did that, I got back to the email with my doubts.

Understanding social¬†media

Before moving on to understanding users‚Äô contexts and problems, I wanted to dive into what contributes to a successful social media strategy. I created this mind map to identify contextual details which will help me in making design decisions during the ideation process. This will also help me understand where Buffer fits holistically.

The company obviously contributes to tooling, but I also came to know about their other product offerings from their CEO Joel¬†Gascoigne‚Äôs recent tweet.¬†üëá

The tweet made me want to brainstorm ideas on¬†how to potentially increase the usage of other products by leveraging the most popular one.

Constraints/technology

I made assumptions from my personal experience on how teams or individuals use Buffer in their day-to-day workflow.

For the scope of this exercise, I will be focusing on the ‚Äúplan‚Äù and ‚Äúaction‚Äù aspect of the workflow.

Buffer already has reputable products¬†across multiple devices. So, I tried to integrate my ideas into existing ecosystems so that they fit organically.

Defining audience

The scope of the tool varies depending on the audience. An individual running a side project would have very limited requirements, while an enterprise company with a global social media team will be completely different.

As a result, I focused on two personas:

  1. Solo entrepreneurs
  2. Small startups with two to three people in their marketing teams

Understanding the users‚Äô contexts and needs

Before jumping to solutions, it is better to understand the contexts on when/where the app will be used and the current challenges users face.

I love the jobs-to-be-done (JTBD)¬†framework, which emphasizes brainstorming on core needs.

Following the framework, I brainstormed¬†why¬†people wanted to know the overview of scheduled content at a glance in a¬†mobile app. I also wanted to know why people would prefer using a mobile app over a desktop, as most traditional software are best viewed on large screens.

Here‚Äôs how I rationalized this:

  • Convenience: People want to access anything from anywhere.
  • Control: People need to be mindful about situations and the content that goes out.
  • Quick: People need to react fast to real-time events and situations.
  • Effective: Having an overview of what goes out for the day is helpful to skim potential mistakes and correct them.
  • Efficient: The ability to work on the go enables people to perform their jobs efficiently.

Next, I listed the good and bad user experiences when people want to get an overview of the scheduled content:

1. Overview experience

  • Good: Individual recommendations show important information for better judgement.
  • Good: Established mobile interaction gestures allow for a delightful experience.
  • Good: The ability to see related texts, links, and images are associated with scheduled content.
  • Bad: Dense display of information increases anxiety and confusion.

2. Spotting gaps

  • Good: Easy visual representation makes finding gaps easier.
  • Bad: No visual or overlap of content increases frustration and hinders the ability to perform the job correctly.

3. Filling gaps

  • Good: Supports existing platforms to enable the easy sharing of content
  • Bad: Forces people to go to multiple screens or go through multiple steps in order to share content

Exploring ideas

The following helped with my approach:

  • Buffer‚Äôs open blog
  • Their design principle ‚ÄúBe clear, not clever‚Äù
  • Tyler for answering my doubts and providing helpful links¬†üëç

How people use it¬†now

To understand how people currently use the service, I sourced all the inspiration from the existing patterns in Buffer‚Äôs web and mobile apps.

Lightning demo

I love doing lightning demos with the team. For this, we generally present ideas or any existing solutions we love in other apps or products. This helps in getting buy-in from the team quickly.

I liked the personal greeting and how it showcases the overall overview of the ecommerce store.

I liked this pattern because it can be potentially used to outbound people who are interested in other product offerings or promotional campaigns.

I loved Headspace design because of their branding and marketing in social media. I also liked how the design is consistent across iOS and Android devices.

Rough sketches

One of the first tasks I wanted to handle was information structure to make it fast and easy to get an overview of the content.

I came up with this information architecture:

  1. Introducing the concept of ‚ÄúOrganization‚Äù: Organization will help agencies and people who handle social media for multiple clients. It follows a similar pattern used in Instagram for multiple accounts. Each organization will have multiple social media channels.
  2. Streamlining¬†navigation¬†to three options: Overview, content, and profile.

Next, I brainstormed on how landing screen will look like when users open the app.

Moving to the content screen, I followed the existing pattern in the website with a new addition: grid view.

After defining the basic skeleton and design direction, I directly jumped into Figma to design the UI. I frequently jump from hand-drawn sketches and high-fidelity designs, as it helps me play with new ideas and validate them quickly.

Visual design

For the sake of this exercise, I decided to choose iPhone‚Ää‚ÄäX to design the screens.

Home screen

The home screen is¬†personal¬†and acts as an¬†advisor. It prioritizes what to show based on situation and context. It also acts as a gateway to other screens. It features quick KPIs that social media managers would love to know.

Another factor that led me to redesign the bottom navigation was to avoid conflicting actions with newer iPhone models. On an iPhone X, the physical home button is gone. So, I wanted to¬†avoid an overlap of gestures¬†and provide the action button only where it is needed.

The content on the content tab changes based on recency.¬†The more immediate ones are displayed with extra information with larger photos to let users know what will be going out if unchanged.

I wanted to explore a new feature called ‚Äúpreview‚Äù as well. It will mimic how the post will look like in the local context of the specific social media channel.

This screen shows what will happen when a user taps on ‚Äúmore actions.‚Äù

I also wanted to explore a new feature called ‚Äúsnooze,‚Äù¬†where users can delay the timing of posts instead of moving down the scheduled pipeline.

Individual recommendations or personalized content delights users, and according to research, users don‚Äôt mind privacy concerns if it will help them get their job done effectively. I would love to explore leveraging machine learning to enhance this experience.

Content screen

Following the existing pattern in the web app, I added a grid view. The screen showcases a one-day schedule with the ability to view schedules for the next three days.

The reason behind this constraint is because I didn‚Äôt want to overwhelm users with a barrage of information. The one-day view provides them with enough context to make decisions immediately.

Grid view also features easily identifiable empty slots so people can fill in the gaps.

Though floating action buttons (FABs) are very Android-specific, it is a common pattern in many iOS apps too. I brought in pause queue options here because it felt more intuitive instead of going into settings to pause a queue.

Another micro-interaction I tried to visualize on the content screen is a drawer sliding down when someone taps on the list item. This action is aligned with what was presented at the home screen.

User can:

  • Preview what the post will look like when published.
  • Snooze the post for custom time.
  • Edit the post.
  • Share the post now.

Measure success

The next step was to validate my assumptions by doing usability testing.

To measure the success of this interface and its future iterations, I had to track:

  1. Engagement count‚Ää: Knowing how well the¬†home screen attracts attention.
  2. Compare metrics‚Ää: Comparing key metrics with the old design.
  3. List, grid, or calendar‚Ää: Knowing which view is used the most and why.

My next iterations would include:

  1. Better personal recommendations:¬†Leveraging machine learning to provide more accurate and personal recommendations based on extensive training.
  2. Analytics: More powerful analytics with daily reports and an alert system.
  3. Vertical content: Better support for content that are vertical.
  4. Social media checklists:¬†Linters that identify potential human errors.

***

I‚Äôve barely touched the surface here. One of the challenges I like about designing for consumer apps is that there is no right or wrong answer. It‚Äôs about retrospection and iteration.

Mobile ecosystems are changing every year and we have to adapt to it. This means leveraging the latest innovations in technology to create delightful experiences.

The complete version of this article was first published on UX Collective.
